text: Curt Valentin (5 October 1902, Hamburg, Germany – 19 August 1954, Forte dei Marmi, Italy) was a German-Jewish art dealer known for handling modern art, particularly sculpture, and works classified as "degenerate" by the Nazi regime in pre-war Germany. After 1927 Curt Valentin worked for Alfred Flechtheim in Berlin.Galerie Flechtheim The Frick Collection. Retrieved 12 October 2017. In 1934, he worked at Gallery, Hamburg. In 1937, he emigrated to America, and opened a modern art gallery, Bucholz gallery, in New York City.Curt Valentin Gallery (New York, N.Y.) The Frick Collection. Retrieved 12 October 2017. He had permission to sell German art in America, from the Nazi authorities. In 1951 the gallery was renamed the Curt Valentin Gallery. His gallery operated from 1951, until a year after his death in 1954, and handled works by many notable artists including Alexander Calder, Henry Moore, Marino Marini, and Jacques Lipchitz. ==References== ==External links== *"Curt Valentin in his gallery, ca. 1952", Photography by Adolph Studly, at Archives of American Art *Ludwig Meidner: "Curt Valentin", MOMA *Marino Marini and Curt Valentin: The Rise of the Italian Sculptor in America. *"Artnews : MOMA's problematic provenances" *"Bridges from the Reich: The Importance of Émigré Art Dealers as Reflected in the Case Studies of Curt Valentin and Otto Kallir– Nirenstein" Category:American art dealers Category:1902 births Category:1954 deaths Category:Emigrants from Nazi Germany to the United States Category:German art dealers
